basics.name: Emillia E. Noordhoek
basics.label: Program Management & Community Development
basics.summary: I am a creative and energetic global thinker and a leader in implementing community project objectives by working really hard in challenging and sometimes hostile situations. In many of the places I have worked in emotions run high as the communities I am working with have a legacy of being disenfranchised through culturally and economically. I think that most citizens of the US feel that there is so much at stake in the way our current culture politics are running the world and not engaging people in true conversation that illicit change of behavior and this causes anxiety on so many levels. All communities seek agency over their resources, lands and culture, it is my most humble and proud work in collaboration with people in Hawaii and around the globe to help to achieve this goal. My skill set is incredibly diverse, being a successful social entrepreneur to sustainable building designer and working artistically with the community. I have a brain and soul that want to be engaged and learn new things, fight for social and environmental justice and create beauty that begins a conversation on vital issues to our culture and democracy. I am a passionate politically active woman who really does in the power of a democracy and that our legacy in continually improving upon it is paying it forward to future generations.

work.summary: You must include a description here
highlights: Current Project Community Liaison and development lead for Groundswell, community solar, non- profit developer to develop a project for Molokai for the Community Based Renewable Energy(CBRE) pilot project phase 1.
Held public community meetings to engage the Molokai community about the Community Based Renewable Energy(CBRE) Projects.
Worked with Utility, developer and land owner to gather bids for construction of project in order to develop market for cost share from the community.
Offer Environmental and Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED) consulting services to private clients and grassroots community organizations

work.summary: You must include a description here
highlights: Manage and execute daily organizational operations, including: program implementation; community relations and organizing; program evaluation; staff and consultant management of 5 staff and 30 plus volunteers; and oversight of a $400,000 budget.

Conceptualize and lead vision and strategy development for the energy and renewable resources portfolio, which includes education in energy efficiency and renewable energy programming as part of a community plan that is environmentally and economically sustainable and resilient.

Serve as the Moloka‘i community representatives and liaison in the negotiations between Maui Electric Companies Power Purchase Agreement with a solar developer. In this role, worked to ensure the Moloka‘i community benefits package includes a fair and equitable rate with an appropriate benefits package.

Co-created the Tentou Network, an international energy cohort of 5 organizations seeking to follow the example lead by Samso Island, Denmark (100% reliant on fossil fuels to 100% renewable, community owned power in 10 years).

Secured $9.6 million in public financing through the Hawaii Green Infrastructure Authority to provide revolving loans for 1,200 homes, 30% of the households on Moloka‘i, to participate in a solar water heater exchange program.

Develop and manage the HUI UP! Program, which focuses on getting more energy efficient appliances in homes. Over seven years, in partnership with Blue Planet Foundation, Hawaii Energy, and the Moloka‘i community, we have impacted over 1000 homes (25% of homes on Moloka‘i) by exchanging 36,000 incandescent light bulbs for CFLs and close appliances expanding from refrigerators to washers, dryers and AC Units. This is projected to save community residents over $1 million in energy costs over the next 10 years.
Develop and manage the energy audit program, which includes training and mentoring 25 youth to conduct energy audits in 650 participating Moloka‘i households.

Develop and manage the Directed Restoration Project, which focuses on repurposing defunct quarry land into a viable bamboo farm for biomass energy products. This included coordinating a team from the Dutch renewable energy firm ECN 2016 to conduct a feasibility study to utilize waste bamboo.

work.summary: You must include a description here
highlights: Lead the facilitation and process to replace the midterm local legislative seat for State Representative.

Organize and oversee local polling places for 2016 presidential caucuses, training precinct presidents to count and report the votes accurately in a contested and sometimes hostile field of engaged citizens. Worked with the Hawaii State Democratic Party state convention to ensure an appropriate number of delegates to each candidate in a transparent way for the national democratic conventions.
Wrote and submitted to the Hawaii State Democratic Party three separate resolutions to the Democratic Platform addressing climate change mitigation through Agriculture, and the use of fossil fuels.

work.summary: You must include a description here
highlights: Decided project feasibility, developed and managed project budgets, secured $1.2 million in project financing from private and public sources to build homes for local families and renovate existing housing stock with energy efficiency and solar.

Coordinated with local and national EPA officials to create criteria for Hawaii Energy Star certification for housing throughout the state for the first EPA certified Energy Star homes in the state of Hawaii. Project manager of the first energy-independent, off grid bamboo kit home for Moloka‘i Habitat for Humanity.

Raised legislative awareness on affordable housing issues for creating policy to integrate renewable energy systems, citing the high cost of energy as a “hidden cost” of housing that burdens middle to low-income families that lead to the funding of Energy Efficiency programs for low to moderate-income families on Moloka‘i.

volunteer.summary:
• Conducted research and document review for IRP AG for the Utilities long range plans to reach 100% renewables by 2045.
  • Represent the Moloka‘i ratepayers in the IRP AG process, translate utilities interconnection plan documents for Moloka‘i.
  • See my write up in the Moloka`i energy assessment for further information on this faked process by the utility to pretend they were making head way on the renewables promise when they were not pulling the state forward.

• Founded the first art center on Moloka‘i.
  • Implemented free youth arts classes, college art classes and built capacity in community for local jobs.
  • Worked my ass off raising funds, writing grants, selling pottery and teaching classes
  • Developed and organized the annual fundraiser the Soup`R bowlnow in it’s 10th year!
  • Crated the artist in residence program and worked with the local community to make it successful
  • Kids classes
  • Trained local artist in raku, wood firing, salt and soda firing
  • Built kilns
  • Volunteered over 1000 hrs making bowls, teaching, fundraising and talking to people to fund and support the only art center on Molokai.

education.institution: The University of Oregon, School of Architecture and Allied Arts
education.area: Major in sculpture and pottery, minor in education.
Art Education, Museum Studies, and Japanese Porcelain

courses: credential as a Leadership in Energy and Environmental Designs( LEED) Associate Professional (AP) through the U.S Green Building Council,2nd LEED AP in the State of Hawaii in 2006

awards.title: Omidyar Fellowship- Forum of Fellows
awards.summary: Omidyar Fellows is an enduring and ongoing commitment to an active network of leaders and change-makers, all of whom are dedicated to making positive movement on Hawaii’s most pressing issues. Fellows also commit to the ongoing development of their leadership and its impact in Hawaii. We follow a 15-month cohort program then afterward become part of the greater forum of fellows across the state, nation, and world. This is a unique forum as we continue to develop the governing structure and peer support based on native Hawaiian cultural values and the value of Aloha. I am currently representing my cohort on the governing board called the Ho`okela, quarterly meetings and relating information about programs and board relations back to the cohort. This was the inspiration of Pierre and Pam Omidyar and is part of the Omidyar group legacy in Hawaii.

awards.title: Artist Residence Program in Support of inscription of Aso as a World Heritage Site
awards.summary: The purpose of this program is to offer a creative environment for overseas artists in the Aso district. Artists will create artworks featuring Aso and expected to promote and network information concerning the importance of the UN world heritage site through their artworks. My artwork was created with the assistance of the local, rural community and is on display at the municipality in Minimiaso. Not only was I responsible to create a community piece but I am also tasked with fulfilling the goal of talking about my experience to diverse audiences in the USA mainland and Hawaii.

awards.title: Sunday Mornings at the European Keramic Work Center (EKWC)
awards.summary: Three months artist in residency program at the world-renowned ceramic center researching and creating large scale sculpture on social and political issues including climate change, discrimination, racism and sexual harassment with the goal to address the trauma caused by such events on an individual and community level. The work is place-based and community-centered to encourage engagement and discussion to promote collaborative problem solving and healing.

awards.title: Hawai’i Investment Ready-Cohort III
awards.summary: HIR is a two-year program designed to help social ventures better understand and scale their impact and business models, and to assist them in accessing resources to implement their next level of growth. Worked with coaches and venture capital to take the abstract vision that was vaguely articulated at the closing of the conference and transmute the various intentions that made up this abstraction into a thriving tangible entity that continues to produce value for the island of Molokai. In starting and building Sustainable Molokai I showed my ability to transform disintegrated resources into an aggregated tangible expression of the vision of the community of Molokai.

awards.title: Hawai’i Alliance for Progressive Action
awards.summary: The core of HAPA’s mission is to catalyze community empowerment and systemic change - a change that goes to the root of our social, economic and environmental injustices. In order to fulfill that mission, HAPA believes that Hawai‘i needs more progressive government leaders who value ʻāina (environment or 'that which feeds') and people ahead of corporate profit. The fellowship allowed me to create greater connections throughout the state of Hawaii through political parties and assist in running people for office, increasing my capacity for community organizing, and working with candidates on a local state and national context for powerful change.
